message_1: A spaceship moves away from the Earth with a velocity of 0.6c. It emits a signal at a frequency of 10 MHz. Calculate the frequency observed by an observer on Earth if the speed of sound is negligible.
message_2:
To calculate the frequency observed by an observer on Earth, we need to use the Doppler effect formula for electromagnetic waves, which takes into account the relativistic effects due to the high speed of the spaceship.

The formula for the Doppler effect in the case of electromagnetic waves is:

f_observed = f_emitted * sqrt((1 - v/c) / (1 + v/c))

where f_observed is the frequency observed on Earth, f_emitted is the frequency emitted by the spaceship (10 MHz), v is the velocity of the spaceship (0.6c), and c is the speed of light.

Plugging in the values:

f_observed = 10 MHz * sqrt((1 - 0.6c/c) / (1 + 0.6c/c))

f_observed = 10 MHz * sqrt((1 - 0.6) / (1 + 0.6))

f_observed = 10 MHz * sqrt(0.4 / 1.6)

f_observed = 10 MHz * sqrt(0.25)

f_observed = 10 MHz * 0.5

f_observed = 5 MHz

So, the frequency observed by an observer on Earth is 5 MHz.
